title: Which one is correct, 'I don't knew' or ' I didn't know '? Do they mean the same thing? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't knew" or " I didn't know "? Do they mean the same thing? “I don't knew”. Knew is the past tense form of the verb ‘know’. We don't say either “I don't knew” or ‘I didn't knew’. When we make negatives with do, we construct them in the form of ‘don't + (present tense of) verb’. I don't like. I don't want. I don't know. I don't see. I don't understand. ‘I don't know’ and ‘I didn't know’. I don't know who she is. Present tense. I have no idea who she is. I didn't know who she was. Past tense. I had no idea about her earlier, in the past. I didn't know anything about her until an year ago (when we accidentally met and became friends). “When is he coming”? “I don't know”. “I didn't even know that he was planning to come”. ‘I don't know’ is also a discourse marker in spoken English. That is, when you are short of words or when you are not sure what to say or when you are too lazy to explain.… …this phrase comes in quite handy. :)

“I don’t knew.” is wrong. So what it means is not important. “I didn’t know.” is correct. And it is an example of Simple Past Tense. It means “I did not know something in past”. As “did” is a verb in Past Tense, the other verb “know” is written in Present Tense and not as “knew” in Present Tense. Rule: Two verbs in Past Form cannot come together in same sentence. Example: Wrong “I didn’t wrote anything worth appreciation.” Right I didn’t write anything worth appreciation.” Hope it helped.
